snippet.textDisplay:
I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called "Linux", and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called "Linux" distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.

I use gentoo and arch linux btw.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called "Linux", and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. All the so-called "Linux" distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.

I use gentoo and arch linux btw.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you Linus and LTT for promoting Linux a bit more..


The Pi 1B was my first intro to Linux, back then things were allot harder, ie it took my skills as an more hardware tech and my friend a software tech to get some nice features going....now it's plug and play, For all beginners Ubuntu and Mint will be a great start, especially if web browsing, word processing and watching movies are all you do.
For those who want to game...Yes proton for steam has really come a long way and there are other options like Linux play and Lutris (Thx again to LTT bringing Level1gaming on for show and tell), but it's not all cut and dry.
If tried, use and tested, Ubuntu, Mint, MX linux, Debian and on the Pi raspbian....depending on a few factors with gaming, MX was better than Ubuntu out of the gate, then Mint will setup in no time But give an issue with some game. On Ubuntu my Age of empires 2 would not work on Ubuntu steam proton but would work on the same OS with Lutris.....
THere are some setup and sequence of events to follow to get things right.
Best way to go if migrating to Linux, get a 2nd drive pop it in......install linux on that drive and start playing, and then install another OS and try it etc. Install a game on you steam library in windows and linux then you can compare the difference, but do remember some things can be a WTF moment, ie before I fucked up my Linux when installing Win10 (and I still blame you win 10), getting Skyrim to work with skse and mods can be a learning curve vs windows.
PS your typing skill will improve due to the terminal.....and you do kind of feel more in control and remember google is your friend "how to THIS in Linux"
To new Linux users have fun and explore

For those who want to game...Yes proton for steam has really come a long way and there are other options like Linux play and Lutris (Thx again to LTT bringing Level1gaming on for show and tell), but it's not all cut and dry.
If tried, use and tested, Ubuntu, Mint, MX linux, Debian and on the Pi raspbian....depending on a few factors with gaming, MX was better than Ubuntu out of the gate, then Mint will setup in no time But give an issue with some game. On Ubuntu my Age of empires 2 would not work on Ubuntu steam proton but would work on the same OS with Lutris.....
THere are some setup and sequence of events to follow to get things right.
Best way to go if migrating to Linux, get a 2nd drive pop it in......install linux on that drive and start playing, and then install another OS and try it etc. Install a game on you steam library in windows and linux then you can compare the difference, but do remember some things can be a WTF moment, ie before I fucked up my Linux when installing Win10 (and I still blame you win 10), getting Skyrim to work with skse and mods can be a learning curve vs windows.
PS your typing skill will improve due to the terminal.....and you do kind of feel more in control and remember google is your friend "how to THIS in Linux"
To new Linux users have fun and explore

snippet.textDisplay:
Linux has come a long ways, but I still prefer Windows over it. And Perhaps Windows 10 interrupted you earlier than 2019, but since I installed it in 2019, it has never interrupted me for an update. I can schedule them for any time at my leisure. The one thing I have liked about Windows is when there are flaws in it and things people dislike, Microsoft has a history of correcting these things. And as someone else mentioned, if I want to play World of Warships, I'll need Windows (I do play it and have it installed). And no, I am not fiddling around with whine or some such other nonsense. I can't stand how Linux has it's file "organization" etc. It's certainly much better than it used to be. I do recall in one test a few years ago that I found Linux to run a little laggy when it came to multitasking. I wouldn't mind seeing some tests in this regard. I see tests in single tasks, but when I ran more than one program at a time, I noticed a slowdown I didn't like at the time. A modern system may not notice this, but I still feel it may be a problem. Anyhow, I just got all t he Linux fanboys angry so my work is done. ;)

Oh, and if you're going to apt-get, you need to know the name of the program to get, which it is really great for but I can search online and download just as fast.
snippet.textOriginal:
Linux has come a long ways, but I still prefer Windows over it.  And Perhaps Windows 10 interrupted you earlier than 2019, but since I installed it in 2019, it has never interrupted me for an update.  I can schedule them for any time at my leisure.  The one thing I have liked about Windows is when there are flaws in it and things people dislike, Microsoft has a history of correcting these things.  And as someone else mentioned, if I want to play World of Warships, I'll need Windows (I do play it and have it installed).  And no, I am not fiddling around with whine or some such other nonsense.  I can't stand how Linux has it's file "organization" etc.  It's certainly much better than it used to be.  I do recall in one test a few years ago that I found Linux to run a little laggy when it came to multitasking.  I wouldn't mind seeing some tests in this regard.  I see tests in single tasks, but when I ran more than one program at a time, I noticed a slowdown I didn't like at the time.  A modern system may not notice this, but I still feel it may be a problem.  Anyhow, I just got all t he Linux fanboys angry so my work is done. ;)

Oh, and if you're going to apt-get, you need to know the name of the program to get, which it is really great for but I can search online and download just as fast.

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks for this video...I hope a few people jump the Microsoft ship, which is not a bad ship, but an old one...and give Linux a genuine try. It’s awesome. I bought a Mac and I’m missing my i3 window manager, it was epic. I had it set up so pretty and efficient. Damn I wanna go back now. MacOS isn’t bad either though. So...bottom line...hardware and ecosystem wise Mac rocks, compatibility wise it’s Windows, but close on its heels is Linux, with the added benefit of being “free”; Which one do you think you’d like? All of them make sense...but don’t dismiss one without giving it a good old fashioned try.
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks for this video...I hope a few people jump the Microsoft ship, which is not a bad ship, but an old one...and give Linux a genuine try. It’s awesome. snippet.textDisplay:
Linux...
You mean UNIX!!!!
Either way: while sure, UNIX/Linux has it's good sides compared to Windows, the main issue is that it just ain't user friendly.
If I want to add a program or game, I have to not just install it, but do a ton of adding and altering stuff.
Though I am familiar with UNIX (this was THE industrial OS yesteryears with Novel Netware for netware support and I was a supervisor for both), it is SUCH a hassle to get things working.
If that was not the case, hell, I'd be running UNIX/Linux, and I want to bet, most even would.
It would be sadly even the death of Microsoft and MacOS, I am sure.
But no, no one seems to bother with making a Windows or MacOS style friendly Unix/Linux.
So sad, really...

Hmmmm... hey ANTHONY... why not see this as a challenge? XD
Make a UNIX/Linux user friendly version suited for all? :P

snippet.textDisplay:
GNU + Linux

I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called "Linux", and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called "Linux" distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I could use more stability and features in my Ubuntu 19.10 at 1080p on QFHD XPS13. Gnome messes up window sizes on resume, Gnome on Wayland lacks compose key and fails to respond to clicks for a while after resume, Xfce froze on suspend, and KDE still lacked onclick notification dismissal and app raise and often broke Chrome's save dialog and the session locker (known since 2016). It is rather nice to suddenly have 128TB RAM according to linuxlogo, though, but reality sets in as screenfetch says RAM: 7183MiB / 15693MiB.
snippet.textOriginal: I could use more stability and features in my Ubuntu 19.10 at 1080p on QFHD XPS13. Gnome messes up window sizes on resume, Gnome on Wayland lacks compose key and fails to respond to clicks for a while after resume, Xfce froze on suspend, and KDE still lacked onclick notification dismissal and app raise and often broke Chrome's save dialog and the session locker (known since 2016). It is rather nice to suddenly have 128TB RAM according to linuxlogo, though, but reality sets in as screenfetch says RAM: 7183MiB / 15693MiB.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. snippet.textDisplay:
I was pleasantly surprised by the mention of stuff like fish and i3, but I thought it was weird that fish/dash were mentioned and zsh wasn't. IIRC dash is just Debian's variant of sh made to be small and fast, not something you'd use as your main shell in most cases, and zsh is more popular than fish. Maybe it was just based on it being less pronounceable than the others.
I would love to see more GNU/Linux content from you guys. Maybe ricing videos or handy small shell scripts you make or find. It would be nice to get a big channel like this one to do a video on Wayland as well. A lot of people keep repeating that it's not ready, but I've been using it since last year and I think it's doing pretty well. I can at least vouch for Sway being good. I haven't tried the Wayland versions of GNOME/KDE or anything else.
snippet.textOriginal:
I was pleasantly surprised by the mention of stuff like fish and i3, but I thought it was weird that fish/dash were mentioned and zsh wasn't. IIRC dash is just Debian's variant of sh made to be small and fast, not something you'd use as your main shell in most cases, and zsh is more popular than fish. Maybe it was just based on it being less pronounceable than the others.
I would love to see more GNU/Linux content from you guys. Maybe ricing videos or handy small shell scripts you make or find. It would be nice to get a big channel like this one to do a video on Wayland as well. A lot of people keep repeating that it's not ready, but I've been using it since last year and I think it's doing pretty well. I can at least vouch for Sway being good. I haven't tried the Wayland versions of GNOME/KDE or anything else.

snippet.textDisplay: I run big data centers for telco, and it’s been on LInux since we moved/ported from Unix V in 1995.  I’m currently running OpenStack on CentOS, Cisco ACI, and Cisco NGF Firewalls.  All of it is controlled by the OpenStack interface which resembles AWS Dashboard.  Storage is all SSD SAN on Purestorage devices.  Launch a new server running anything, including Windows Server, add block storage, schedule backups, configure networking including load balancing, all through a GUI.  My Systems Engineers and Network Engineers keep it running, but creating a new VxLAN, storage allocation, or backup scheduling is all done by the developer or user in an easy to use GUI, just like AWS, but we own all of the hardware.  You can create exact copies of existing servers using a CHEF recipe, since every production machine is built and controlled by CHEF.  Any Developer or Engineer can spin up a complete copy of Production for their own use in a couple of clicks of the mouse.  All thanks to Linux and amazing Systems Engineers who work for me.  When they are done, they can destroy that environment with a few clicks, check code in to a local GIT repository, and then through deployment automation run tests and deploy to Prod while its still running, no downtime.
snippet.textOriginal: I run big data centers for telco, and it’s been on LInux since we moved/ported from Unix V in 1995.  I’m currently running OpenStack on CentOS, Cisco ACI, and Cisco NGF Firewalls.  All of it is controlled by the OpenStack interface which resembles AWS Dashboard.  Storage is all SSD SAN on Purestorage devices.  Launch a new server running anything, including Windows Server, add block storage, schedule backups, configure networking including load balancing, all through a GUI.  My Systems Engineers and Network Engineers keep it running, but creating a new VxLAN, storage allocation, or backup scheduling is all done by the developer or user in an easy to use GUI, just like AWS, but we own all of the hardware.  You can create exact copies of existing servers using a CHEF recipe, since every production machine is built and controlled by CHEF.  Any Developer or Engineer can spin up a complete copy of Production for their own use in a couple of clicks of the mouse.  All thanks to Linux and amazing Systems Engineers who work for me.  When they are done, they can destroy that environment with a few clicks, check code in to a local GIT repository, and then through deployment automation run tests and deploy to Prod while its still running, no downtime.
